div.p: Welcome to our SaaS Notes app. SaaS Notes App is a full-stack application, built with React, Wasp (Web Application Specification Programming) and PostgreSQL. Users are invited to organize a to do list by posting, deleting and crossing out notes as they are completed. This documentation provides an overview of how to run the application, it‚Äôs functionality and testing procedures.
To get started please go to the repository SaaS Notes App and clone the project.
div.h3: Installing and running the app locally for the first time:

ol.li: Make sure you have the most up to date version of Node, even though some of the wasp docs say to have a specific older version. That is outdated and as of March 2024, Wasp can handle the latest version of node.
Install Wasp

Download Docker Desktop
YouTube tutorial: Installing Docker Desktop on Mac

In your VS Code download the extension Wasp. This extension is the VS Code language extension for Wasp.
Extension ID: wasp-lang.wasp
Clone the project into your chosen directory.
Navigate to the root of your new project.
Make sure you have Docker running, open a new terminal and navigate to the app directory inside the project, all of the commands below are in that directory.

In your terminal use the command wasp start db to start the database.
Optional tip: Split your terminal and run both the above commands side by side. you can name the tab ‚ÄúDB‚Äù so you limit the amount of terminal windows
To initialize the database, open a new terminal tab and run wasp db migrate-dev
In a second terminal window use the command wasp start to start the front end
Navigate to localhost: 3000 in your browser to see the app.

div.h3: Running the app locally after the first time:

ol.li: Make sure you have Docker running, open a new terminal and navigate to the app directory inside the project, all of the commands below are in that directory

In your terminal use the command wasp start db to start the database. Leave this terminal open and running. If you wish, you can also open another terminal and run the command wasp db studio to see or manage your DB via Prisma‚Äôs DB Studio GUI in a browser page.
Optional tip: Split your terminal and run both the above commands side by side. you can name the tab ‚ÄúDB‚Äù so you limit the amount of terminal windows

In a second terminal window in the same app directory, first initialize your database, if you haven‚Äôt already, by running the command wasp db migrate-dev. This doesn‚Äôt need to be done every time, only if there hasn‚Äôt already been a migration done or if new data has been added to your database while the app wasn‚Äôt running.
In another terminal window (or the same from #3) use the command wasp start to start the front end. This part might take a bit and will require that terminal stay open.
Navigate to localhost: 3000 in your browser to see the app.
To set up wasp on your device please visit this link Wasp
Be sure to also set up WSL2
Download and install Docker Desktop; both WSL and Docker require a reboot after installation.

Make sure you have the most up to date version of Node, even though some of the wasp docs say to have a specific older version. That is outdated and as of March 2024, Wasp can handle the latest version of node.

In your VS Code download the extension WSL. The¬†WSL extension¬†lets you use VS Code on Windows to build Linux applications that run on the¬†Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL).
Extension ID: ms-vscode-remote.remote-wsl

In your VS Code download the extension ‚ÄòWasp‚Äô. This extension is the VS Code language extension for Wasp.
Extension ID: wasp-lang.wasp
Using an ubuntu terminal, clone the project into your chosen directory.
Make sure you have Docker running and open a new ubuntu terminal and navigate to the app directory inside the project.

In your ubuntu terminal use the command ‚Äòwasp start db‚Äô to start the database. Leave this terminal open and running. If you wish, you can also open another ubuntu terminal and run the command wasp db studio to see or manage your DB via Prisma‚Äôs DB Studio GUI in a browser page.

In a second ubuntu terminal window in the same app directory, first initialize your database, if you haven‚Äôt already, by running the command wasp db migrate-dev. Next, use the command wasp start to start the front end. This part might take a bit.
Navigate to localhost: 3000 in your browser to see the app.

NOTE: if you run into issues with docker suddenly not being found in your ubuntu terminal, try:
right clicking on docker‚Äôs tray icon and choosing restart. or just restart the application
in your normal windows terminal, run the command: wsl --shutdown and then click ok on the prompt that opens up. Now you should be able to follow the steps above, though it might require closing all your ubuntu terminals and opening a new one.
Make sure you have Docker running and open a new ubuntu terminal and navigate to the app directory inside the project. The below commands should all run in this directory.

In your ubuntu terminal use the command wasp start db to start the database. Leave this terminal open and running. If you wish open another ubuntu terminal and run the command wasp db studio to see or manage your DB via Prisma‚Äôs DB Studio GUI in a browser page.
Optional tip: Split your terminal and run both the above commands side by side. you can name the tab ‚ÄúDB‚Äù so you limit the amount of terminal windows

In a second ubuntu terminal window in the same app directory, first initialize your database, if you haven‚Äôt already, by running the command wasp db migrate-dev. This doesn‚Äôt need to be done every time, only if there hasn‚Äôt already been a migration done or if new data has been added to your database while the app wasn‚Äôt running.
Next, In another terminal window (or the same from #3), use the command wasp start to start the front end. This part might take a bit and requires the terminal stay open.
Navigate to localhost: 3000 in your browser to see the app.

NOTE: if you run into issues with docker suddenly not being found in your ubuntu terminal, try:
right clicking on docker‚Äôs tray icon and choosing restart. or just restart the application
in your normal windows terminal, run the command: wsl --shutdown and then click ok on the prompt that opens up. Now you should be able to follow the steps above, though it might require closing all your ubuntu terminals and opening a new one.

div.h1: How We Built This (Use Drop down arrows to see details)

details.p: Wasp (Web Application Specification Programming/Language) is a powerful, developer-friendly domain-specific language (DSL) designed to streamline the process of building full-stack web applications. By abstracting away the complexity and boilerplate code typically associated with such projects, Wasp enables us developers to define the frontend, backend, and deployment aspects of our applications using a concise, readable syntax.

At its core, Wasp aims to bridge the gap between frontend and backend development, allowing developers to focus on the logic and functionality of our applications without getting bogged down in the intricacies of the technology stack. It supports key web development features out of the box, including authentication, database operations, and API integrations, making it an all-encompassing tool for rapidly bringing web applications from concept to production.

Wasp's unique approach combines the simplicity of a high-level specification language with the power of modern web development frameworks and tools. By doing so, it not only accelerates the development process but also ensures that applications are scalable, maintainable, and ready for deployment. For more information on our experience and subjective opinions of wasp, check out our readme at the top of this documentation or the repo.

pre.code: ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ client ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄDemoAppPage.tsx ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ assets ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄbackend.png ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄlogo.png ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄtest.png ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ auth ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄauthWrapper.tsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄEmailVarification.tsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄLoginPage.tsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄPasswordReset.tsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄRequestPasswordReset.tsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄSignupPage.tsx ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄAddNote.jsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄLoginForm.jsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄNote.jsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄSignUpForm.jsx ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ hooks ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄuseColorMode.tsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄuseLocalStorage.tsx ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ pages ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄHome.jsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄLogin.jsx ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄSignUp.jsx ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ static ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄavatar-placeholder.png ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄlogo.png ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test/app ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄDemoAppPage.spec.tsx ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ App.tsx ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.css ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Main.css

details.p: The AddNote component is a React functional component designed to provide a user interface for adding a new note. It's structured to accept props, manage user input, and trigger an action upon a button click
Function Definition: AddNote is defined as a functional component that takes an object as its argument. This object destructures three props:

ul.li: note: A string that represents the current value to be displayed in the input field.
setNote: A function intended to update the state of note when a user types in the input field.
createNote: A function to be called when a user clicks the "Add" button, to add a new note to a list of notes or send it to a backend server.

details.p: The LoginForm component is a React functional component designed to provide a user interface for a login form

ul.li: username: A string representing the current value of the username input field.
password: A string representing the current value of the password input field.
setUsername: A function to update the state of username when the user types in the username input field.
setPassword: A function to update the state of password when the user types in the password input field.
authenticate: A function intended to be called when the user submits the form, to verify the username and password.
type: A string that determines the text displayed on the submit button, allowing for reuse of the form component for different purposes (e.g., "Login", "Sign Up").

Controlled Components: Both input fields are controlled components, meaning React is in charge of their state. The inputs display values based on props and notify changes through event handlers, ensuring the component's UI is always in sync with its state.
Event Handling: The onChange handlers for the input fields ensure that the component's state is updated with the user's input, while the onClick handler for the button triggers authentication.

details.p: The Note component is a React functional component designed to display a note with options to edit, delete, and mark it as important.
useState Hook: The component uses the useStatehook to manage its internal state. Three pieces of state are initialized:

ul.li: note: Holds the current content of the note, initially set to the content prop.
editing: A boolean flag indicating whether the note is in edit mode.
tooltip: A boolean flag to show or hide the tooltip options (delete, edit, and pin)

details.p: The SignUpForm component is a React functional component designed for user registration, incorporating basic validation to ensure that the password and confirm password fields match.

ul.li: useState: Used to declare state variables in functional components.
useEffect: Used to perform side effects in functional components, such as running code in response to state changes

The component accepts several props, including username, password, and confirmPassword for holding form values, setUsername, setPassword, and setConfirmPassword for updating these values, authenticate as a function to handle form submission, and type to customize the button text, allowing for reuse of the form component.
A state variable passwordMatchError is used to store a message indicating whether the passwords match. It's initially an empty string, indicating no error

details.p: useEffect Hook:

ul.li: This effect runs whenever password or confirmPassword changes. It sets passwordMatchError to a non-empty string if the passwords don't match, which will be used to display an error message to the user.
This line conditionally renders an error message if passwordMatchError is not an empty string
The submission button triggers the authenticate function passed as a prop when clicked, but only if there is no password mismatch error. The button's text is determined by the type prop.

details.p: The Login page is a React component designed for user authentication
The SignUp page is a React component designed for handling the user registration process.
The Home component is a React functional component designed to display the note-taking application's main interface

This file serves as the central configuration or specification file for our entire application, encompassing both frontend and backend aspects.
(Wasp is designed to abstract away the complexity of full-stack development, allowing developers to define an application's functionality using a high-level declarative syntax.)
This snippet is a configuration for Wasp.

ul.li: wasp: Specifies the version of Wasp being used ("^0.12.0"), ensuring compatibility and feature availability.
title: Sets the application's title to "Notes App".

head: Contains HTML elements to be included in the <head> section of the HTML document. This includes meta tags for SEO and social media platforms (Open Graph for Facebook and cards for Twitter), as well as scripts for analytics (like Plausible and Google Analytics). These tags help improve the visibility and shareability of the app on the web.

auth: Configures authentication for the application. It specifies:
The userEntity as User, indicating the entity that represents users in the application.
Authentication methods, including a username and password method for development/testing. It's noted that this method should be replaced with more secure methods (like social login or email) in production.
Redirection URLs for authentication success (onAuthSucceededRedirectTo) and failure (onAuthFailedRedirectTo).

db:
Sets the database system to PostgreSQL.
Specifies seeds for the database, allowing for initial data to be loaded during development.
client: Defines the root React component (App) for the frontend of the application.
emailSender: Configures email sending capabilities using SendGrid as the provider. It includes a default "from" email address and name, which should match the account details used with SendGrid.

details.p: This section of code defines the structure of the database and what kind of data will exist inside it.

pre.code:
/* üíΩ Wasp defines DB entities via Prisma Database Models: * https://wasp-lang.dev/docs/data-model/entities */
entity User {=psl id Int @id @default(autoincrement()) email String? @unique username String? @unique createdAt DateTime @default(now()) lastActiveTimestamp DateTime @default(now()) isAdmin Boolean @default(false) stripeId String? checkoutSessionId String? hasPaid Boolean @default(false) subscriptionTier String? subscriptionStatus String? sendEmail Boolean @default(false) datePaid DateTime? credits Int @default(3) gptResponses GptResponse[] contactFormMessages ContactFormMessage[] tasks Task[] files File[] psl=}

details.p: This section of the wasp file defines the apps routes.
For example let‚Äôs break down the first route above:

ul.li: route: This keyword starts the definition of a route in the Wasp app.
LandingPageRoute: This is the name we have given to the route. It's a unique identifier within the Wasp project for this specific route.

path: "/": The path property specifies the URL path that triggers this route. The / denotes the root of the site, meaning this route is what users will be directed to when they visit the base URL of this application.
to: LandingPage: The to property links this route to a page within the Wasp app, identified here as LandingPage. This tells Wasp which page to render when the route is accessed.

details.p: This code snippet defines the entity Task using Prisma Schema Language (PSL), which is part of Prisma, an open-source database toolkit. This entity is essentially a model that represents a table in our database, and each field within an entity represents a column in the table.

pre.code: entity Task {=psl id String @id @default(uuid()) description String time String @default("1") isDone Boolean @default(false) user User @relation(fields: [userId], references: [id]) userId Int createdAt DateTime @default(now()) psl=}

ul.li: Represents a table for storing tasks.

Fields:
id: A unique identifier for each task.
description: A description of the task.
time: A string field, with a default value of "1", which could represent an estimated time to complete the task or a due time.
isDone: A boolean indicating whether the task has been completed, defaulting to false.
user: Links to a User entity to show ownership of the task.
userId: The ID of the user who owns the task.
createdAt: When the task was created.

details.p: This code snippet defines three "actions" in our Wasp project. Actions in Wasp are operations that allow for interaction between the client (frontend) and the server (backend), specifically for creating, updating, or deleting data.
Each action in Wasp has a similar structure, which includes:

ul.li: The action keyword to start the definition.
A unique name for the action (createTask, deleteTask, updateTask).
A function (fn) that points to the actual implementation of the action.
The entities that the action interacts with.
Purpose: Creates a new task.

Function Import: import { createTask } from "@src/server/actions.js" tells Wasp where to find the JavaScript function that implements the action logic. The createTask function is expected to handle the creation of a new task, including saving it to the database.
Entities: [Task] indicates that this action interacts with the Task entity. This means the action likely involves creating a new record in the database table or collection associated with tasks.
Purpose: Deletes an existing task.

Function Import: import { deleteTask } from "@src/server/actions.js" points to the function responsible for deleting a task. The deleteTask function should handle the removal of a task record from the database based on some identifier (e.g., a task ID).
Entities: [Task] shows that this action also interacts with the Task entity, specifically to delete a task record.
Purpose: Updates an existing task.

Function Import: import { updateTask } from "@src/server/actions.js" indicates the function that carries out the task update operation. The updateTask function is responsible for modifying an existing task record in the database, such as changing its description, status, or any other properties.
Entities: [Task] signifies that this action is concerned with the Task entity, aiming to update one or more of its properties.

details.p: This code snippet defines a "query" in our Wasp project. Queries in Wasp are operations designed to retrieve data from the server and make it available to the client (frontend).

ul.li: Purpose: Retrieves all tasks associated with a specific user.

Function Import: import { getAllTasksByUser } from "@src/server/queries.js" tells Wasp where to find the JavaScript function that implements the logic for fetching tasks. The getAllTasksByUser function is expected to query the database for tasks that belong to a particular user, likely based on the user's ID or another unique identifier.

Entities: [Task] indicates that this query interacts with the Task entity. This means the query is focused on retrieving records from the database table or collection associated with tasks, specifically filtering them by user.

details.p: This snippet from a Wasp file defines a custom API endpoint, specifically for handling Stripe webhook events.

This Wasp API endpoint definition sets up a backend route to handle Stripe webhook events. When Stripe sends a webhook event to your application (to the /stripe-webhook path using a POST request), the stripeMiddlewareFn middleware is first invoked to perform any necessary preliminary checks or processing. Then, the main stripeWebhook function is called to handle the event, which may involve interacting with the User entity based on the content of the webhook

pre.code: ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ server ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ auth ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄemail.ts ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄsetUsername.ts ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ scripts ‚îÇ | ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄuserSeed.ts ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ actions.ts ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ queries.ts

details.p: The schema.prisma file defines the data model for a web application using a PostgreSQL database. Our schema specifies how data is organized, including the structure of tables and relationships between them in the database.

ul.li: datasource db: This block defines the database connection. It specifies PostgreSQL as the database provider and uses an environment variable (DATABASE_URL) to securely store the database connection string.

generator client: This block configures the Prisma Client, which is an auto-generated and type-safe query builder for Node.js & TypeScript. It specifies that the Prisma Client should be generated using JavaScript (prisma-client-js).

details.p: The schema defines several models, which correspond to tables in the PostgreSQL database. Each model has fields that represent columns in the table, with types and constraints:

ul.li: User: Represents users of the application. It includes fields for user identification, authentication, and metadata (like email, username, isAdmin etc.). It also includes relations to other models like Task
Task: Represents tasks created by users, with fields for description, status, and ownership.
Auth, AuthIdentity, Session: These models are related to authentication and session management, allowing for tracking of user sessions and identities across different authentication providers.

details.summary: How to Run and verify Vitest Test

ol.li:
Make sure you have installed ‚Äòvitest‚Äô with the command
npm install vitest --save-dev

Now run the command
wasp test client run

If you see the below error below:> echo "Error: no test specified" && exit 1
Error: no test specified
navigate to the package.json file and under ‚Äòscripts‚Äô change the test script to "test":"vitest"

After making that change, run
wasp test client run

The test will run in the terminal and will show which tests pass and fail:
ex:

div.p: The following test are located in the client directory:

details.p: We are using Vitest for testing and @testing-library/react for rendering and interacting with React components. This suite focuses on testing the DemoApp component, particularly its functionality related to tasks (e.g., displaying, deleting, and creating tasks).

ul.li: renderInContext: A utility from wasp/client/test for rendering components within the necessary context required by Wasp, ensuring that global states, routing, etc., are correctly set up for the test environment.

Vitest Functions: test, expect, vi, and beforeEach are imported from Vitest, the testing framework. These are used to define test cases (test), make assertions (expect), mock functions or modules (vi), and set up conditions that are applied before each test case (beforeEach).
Testing Library Utilities: screen and fireEvent are imported from @testing-library/react for querying the DOM and simulating user events.
Wasp Client Operations: deleteTask, useQuery, getAllTasksByUser, and createTask are operations provided by Wasp for interacting with the backend. These are being mocked in this test suite.
DemoApp Component: The component we are testing in this suite

details.p: Next, a mockTasks array is defined to simulate a list of tasks that might be fetched from the backend. This mock data is used to provide consistent test conditions.

This test verifies that a task can be deleted from the DemoApp component. It renders the component, checks for the presence of predefined tasks, simulates a click on the delete button for the first task, and then asserts that the deleteTask operation was called with the correct task ID. This test ensures that the component correctly interacts with the delete operation when a user attempts to remove a task.

This test checks that all tasks are correctly rendered by the DemoApp component. After rendering the component, it asserts that the useQuery hook was called to fetch tasks. It then verifies the presence of tasks and their completion status by checking the state of checkboxes associated with each task. This test ensures that the component successfully fetches and displays tasks, accurately reflecting their completion status.

This test focuses on the task creation feature of the DemoApp component. It renders the component, simulates user input to enter a new task description, simulates a click on the submit button, and then asserts that the createTask operation was called with the expected task description. This test validates that the component can take user input and correctly initiate the task creation process.

This test suite focuses on testing the ‚ÄòLoginPage‚Äô component. We are using @testing-library/react for rendering components and querying the DOM, and using a MemoryRouter from react-router-dom to simulate routing context required by components that are using routing features.

The vi.mock function is used to mock the wasp/client/auth module. Specifically, it mocks the useAuth hook and a LoginForm component. The LoginForm is mocked to return a div with the text "LoginForm Mock", which simplifies the test by not rendering the actual form.
"Tests for LoginPage" is defined using
describe. It contains a single test case, "LoginPage should render", which checks if the LoginPage component renders correctly.
Inside the test case, the useAuth hook is further mocked to return an object with data set to null. This setup simulates the scenario where no user is currently authenticated.
The LoginPage component is rendered within a MemoryRouter to provide the necessary routing context.

lastly, the test asserts that a text element with the content "Don't have an account yet?" is present in the document. This assertion checks if the LoginPage correctly displays a prompt or link for users to create a new account, indicating that the component has rendered as expected.

details.summary: Getting to know and setting up Cypress
details.p: To set up Cypress for end-to-end (E2E) testing in your project, follow these steps:

ol.li: Create a New directory for Cypress: If you haven't already, create a new project directory for your Cypress E2E tests.

details.p: 2.Initialize NPM: Navigate to your project directory and initialize a new NPM project by running:

pre.code: npm init -y

ol.li: Install Cypress: Install Cypress as a development dependency in your project by running:

pre.code: npm install --save-dev cypress

details.p: 4.Add npm Script: Add an npm script to your package.json file to run Cypress. Open your package.json file and add the following script:

ol.li: Start the Application: Start your application in test mode. This might involve setting the NODE_ENV environment variable to test. Add a script to your backend package.json to start the application in test mode.
Run Cypress: Now, you can run Cypress by executing the following command in your terminal:

pre.code: npm run cypress:open

ol.li: Create a New Spec File: In the Cypress Test Runner, click on "E2E Testing" to create a new E2E test. Select your preferred browser (e.g., Chrome), and then click "Create new spec". This will create a new spec file where you can write your E2E tests.
Write Your E2E Tests: In the spec file, you can start writing your E2E tests using Cypress' API. Refer to Cypress documentation and guides for writing effective E2E tests.

details.summary: How to run and verify Cypress test

ol.li: After installing Cypress with the command below, Check that Docker is runningnpm install cypress --save-dev
If you have not already, run the following command:npm i --save-dev @types/node

Check that the front end & database are running in your terminals
Remember the database is run with the command ‚Äòwasp start db‚Äô
Remember the front end is run with the command ‚Äòwasp start‚Äô

If you run into the error below:‚ùå --- [Error] Your wasp project failed to compile: -------------------------------
- Error: Dependency conflict for user dependency (@types/node, ^18.19.24): Version must be set to the exactly the same version as the one wasp is using: ^18.0.0
navigate to the package.json file and under ‚ÄòdevDependencies‚Äô change the @types/node dependency to
"@types/node": "^18.0.0‚Äù ,

Now run the command
npm run cypress:open
Select E2E testing on the Cypress UI that pops up.

Then select
Start E2E Testing In Electron

Now you will see the test file names listed
click on the individual test to see test results
Notice the term ‚ÄòSpecs‚Äô at the top of each test. Next to Specs you will see a green check mark next to a red X. Here you will see a number next to one of them indicating if the test has passed or failed
Below that section is the TEST BODY section which provides details about the passed or failed test.

details.p: This test script outlines a test case for the login page, focusing on several key functionalities: displaying the login form, handling an incorrect login attempt, and navigating to the signup page.
We begin by importing custom commands from '../support/commands', which can be used to extend Cypress's testing capabilities with custom functions.
The describe function is used to group related tests together. In this case, it groups tests related to the "Login Page."

ul.li: Inside the describe block, the it function defines a single test case. The description of the test case will cover displaying the login form, handling an incorrect login attempt, and redirecting to the signup page.

ol.li: Visit Login Page: Each test within the describe block first begins by navigating to the application's login page using cy.visit('http://localhost:3000/').

Form & Page Elements: It then checks for the existence of the login form and its elements (username and password inputs, and the login button) to ensure they are visible to the user. The test verifies the presence of texts and links related to account creation ("Don't have an account yet?"), forgotten passwords ("Forgot your password?"), and their respective actions ("go to signup", "reset it").

Attempt Incorrect Login: The script simulates an incorrect login attempt by typing wrong credentials into the username and password fields and clicking the login button. It expects to see a message indicating an "Invalid credentials".
Navigate to Signup Page: The test simulates a user action to navigate to the signup page by clicking on the "go to signup" link and verifies that the URL includes '/signup'.

details.p: The test checks several key aspects of the app, including navigation, conditional rendering based on the presence of notes, and interaction with UI elements.

ol.li: The test begins by navigating to the demo app's page at http://localhost:3000/demo-app.

Next, the test navigates to http://localhost:3001/auth/me, to ensure that the user is logged in. This step is checking if the navigation to an authenticated route is successful, and that the user session is active.

The test then queries for elements with a class of .notes to determine if any notes are currently displayed on the page. This is done using cy.get('.notes'), and the result is passed to a callback function for further logic based on the presence or absence of notes:
If notes are present ($notes.length > 0), the test expects to find visible text on the page that says "Notes found".
If no notes are present, the test expects to find visible text saying "No notes found".
The test simulates a user action by clicking on an "Add Notes" button.

Finally, the test checks for the visibility of a modal (.modal) on the page. This step verifies that the UI responds as expected to the user's action to add a new note, by displaying a modal where the note's details can be entered.

details.p: The test suite contains three test cases that check various aspects of the signup page to ensure it behaves as expected for users who are navigating to this page to create a new account.

strong.strong: Test 1: Display of the Signup Form

li.p: This test verifies that the signup form and related elements are correctly displayed on the page.

ul.li: The test checks for the existence of the form element, ensuring the signup form is present. It also verifies that the current URL includes '/' . Lastly, it looks for text indicating the option to go to the login page if the user already has an account, confirming the presence of navigational aids for users.

li.p: This test is checking if users can successfully sign up with valid credentials and are then redirected to the application.

ul.li: The test inputs a username and a password into the respective fields and submits the form. It then checks if the URL includes 'demo-app', indicating successful redirection post-signup. This test assumes that the provided credentials are valid and that the account does not already exist.

strong.strong: Test 3: Validation of Account Submission Attempts

li.p: This test checks that the signup form validates user input, specifically testing password requirements and unique account constraints.

ul.li: First, it attempts to sign up with a password that does not meet the specified criteria and checks for a validation message.
Next, it tries to sign up with a username that already exists and checks for an error message indicating that an account with the same identity already exists.
